ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained new and practical knowledge on how academic and scientific writing is done.
I learned how to effectively present scientific information orally and visually. I also learned about the effects of certain stylistic and presentational choices on the audience's processing of info.

I learned a lot! Firstly, I learned Yale has many resources for research such as librarians, GIS, EndNote, etc., and that I should definitely consult librarians when it comes to future research topics. I also learned how to properly write scientific papers, including implementing citations. Overall, you learn how to present information effectively and coherently through visuals and speaking. With that in mind, you learn skills outside the classroom, such as interacting with professionals inside the lab and applying the criticism that is given to your work in order to improve.
I learned very useful and practical skills about writing a scientific report and creating presentations.
Learned how to present in appropriate manner and write a research paper correctly
I learned how to present well and in a formal manner.
I learned how to communicate research in a way that knowledgeable and knowledgeable audience can understand. I also learned how to conduct lab work.
Skills to research and communicate the findings in an effective manner.
Time Management and determination to finish a task, as well as many public speaking skills

I believe that this class allowed me to develop skills in scientific communication, presentation, and writing. I found that I was progressively better able to communicate the science behind my research.
N/A
Research presentation skills and paper writing skills.
How to effectively present and write about research. There was a lot of emphasis on presentations and slideshows
I developed key skills in presenting and writing about science academia. I also learned how to access Yale's resources of scientific knowledge from the library and other databases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is really good so far. I would say it would be even more better if the instructions are more straightforward.
Some of the lectures were pretty intuitive. We didn't need to review the parts of speech, for example. I wish we were given more examples of strong oral presentations.

I believe the frequent oral presentations and the frank feedback was a strength of this course. Because students are not required to present everyday, there was the tendency for students to do other work while their peers presented. Eventually, some students began not coming to class on the days they were not presenting. Unless students are giving direct feedback to their peers, they likely won't want to rewatch the same presentation week after week.

Strengths: Many skills learned. Weaknesses: Because the program is so short, everyone in the class is at different points of research and data collection. At the 5 and 6-week mark, the organization of the class starts to get a little messy because many of us do not have data yet. Without data, it gets difficult writing our papers and creating our presentations-- thus making our work less coherent and resulting in point deductions . When we end up collecting data at the 7 week mark, it gets hectic because we would need to rewrite our papers and reorganize our presentations.
Overall the course is taught very well. However, adding scientific lab skills such as pipetting, making gels, etc could be useful.
loved how close knit it was. can always find help if you need it. was a little disorganized but it did not bother me
Needs to be organized better in terms of assignments.

strengths: a lot of good feedback.
weakness: sometimes the tas and the profs are not in accordance.
Class didnt help very much outside of the presentations. Paper felt like we had to do it a lot by ourselves with little guidance.
Lectures were sometimes a little forced and not planned, but overall helped us with structuring a scientific paper and presenting scientific information in the best way possible
I enjoyed how the presentations and paper were broken up into chunks so that the workload felt more manageable. I also enjoyed how we were broken up into sections for the presentations.
N/A
It was very intense and I felt that even though it said results were not required, I felt pressure from my professors to have them.

Strengths were that it really dove deep into presentations and how to have good flow within your presentations.  However, the main weakness was the fast-paced nature of the class and the excessive amount of presentations we had to give.

The strength of the course lies in effective feedback of presentation from formulating slides to presenting with body and voice. The gradual buildup of the paper was also a high strength of the course as it allowed me to build upon the sections of the paper. However, I felt the assignments could be explained better as I was confused about a lot of the assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! it was really helpful!
I thought I gained a lot of new skills from this course, and I feel more confident in delivering scientific material to an audience.
I definitely would. This class really gave me the practice to feel comfortable with speaking publicly. It also taught me how to create simple yet effective presentations.

I would definitely recommend that you take this class if you're given the opportunity to take it. If you haven't done research before, you learn how to speak and present information to an audience, you learn how to organize information in essays in an effective and coherent manner, and you learn how to critically think in the lab (along with professionally interact with your mentor and PI). The presentation at the end is a sweet way of seeing the fruition of your efforts over the past 8 weeks, no matter how heavy the workload may have been. It's also a good bridge because a lot of our peers at Yale already had this experience coming in, and we (who don't have the experience) finally get the chance to catch on.
I would highly recommend this course as it really facilitated my learning through instant feedback. As someone who wasn't exposed to research, this course was very valuable!
yes, I thin it helps develop presentation skills and correctly writing a research paper
Need to take it for stars
yes, if you want to learn how to communicate research
Yes, it is helpful in becoming better with public speaking and presentations. Everyone improved.
I would recommend this course to other students performing research
Yes, especially if they want to be able to learn how to communicate science effectively.
N/A
I would since it gives you a unique opportunity to get into research and practice presenting. It also gives you the foundation to write a research paper.
Yes if they adjust the workload of the class and if you're pursuing a career in research/academia.
Yes, this was a great help in learning how to write and present scientific literature. This is an incredible class for anyone who is looking to go into science as these skills are very important.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will use it throughout my research career and undergraduate life. I will use it for day-to-day research I will pursue throughout Yale and for writing my academic reports and papers for Research for credits.

In future presentations, I desire to speak in a cadence that is slow enough for me to think and enunciate my words. I will strategically make use of breaths to gather my thoughts. I will limit distracting hand movements and make eye contact with the audience. I will avoid visual clutter on my slides and not include an element that does not carry important info.

The class gave me a lot of clarity in approaching other STEM courses, especially in my future lab classes. The scientific report at the end really teaches you how to properly write an abstract or summary of a lab report. It's also helpful in the presentation aspect, because when you need to present in future classes, you know not to use filler words or move a lot anymore. It also taught me to ask for help!
I will use this knowledge to write reports for any future labs and in creating presentations to present in classes and labs that require it.
Helps a lot with my speech and writing simpler
I learned how to present and give feedback to my peers as well.
I will use all that I have learned to better communicate my research in the future. I am also sticking with my lab from this summer.
Public speaking will be essential to any future career I choose to pursue
I think these skills can be applied if I decide to not continue a career STEM. I lot of skills I learned were invaluable for communication in general.
N/A
I'm excited to continue research in my lab and the skills I learned this summer will be extremely valuable if I decide to ever write a thesis or attend a conference.
The skills I learned will be very helpful in any future career I pursue, as I will need to read, write, and present in any profession.
I will use the knowledge and skills I learned heavily since I am planning to go into science. Beyond that, writing is an incredibly important skill in life and this class helped polish it.
